clientbound.name: Cookie Request (configuration)
clientbound.notes: Requests a cookie that was previously stored.

fields.name: Key
fields.notes: The identifier of the cookie.

clientbound.name: Clientbound Plugin Message (configuration)
clientbound.notes:
Mods and plugins can use this to send their data. Minecraft itself uses several plugin channels . These internal channels are in the minecraft namespace.

More information on how it works on Dinnerbone's blog . More documentation about internal and popular registered channels are here .

fields.name: Channel
fields.notes: Name of the plugin channel used to send the data.

fields.name: Data
fields.notes: Any data, depending on the channel. Typically this would be a sequence of fields using standard data types, but some unofficial channels have unusual formats. There is no length prefix that applies to all channel types, but the format specific to the channel may or may not include one or more length prefixes (such as the string length prefix in the standard minecraft:brand channel). The vanilla client enforces a length limit of 1048576 bytes on this data, but only if the channel type is unrecognized.

fields.name: Reason
fields.notes: The reason why the player was disconnected.

clientbound.name: Finish Configuration
clientbound.notes:
Sent by the server to notify the client that the configuration process has finished. The client answers with Acknowledge Finish Configuration whenever it is ready to continue.

This packet switches the connection state to play .

clientbound.name: Clientbound Keep Alive (configuration)
clientbound.notes:
The server will frequently send out a keep-alive, each containing a random ID. The client must respond with the same payload (see Serverbound Keep Alive ). If the client does not respond to a Keep Alive packet within 15 seconds after it was sent, the server kicks the client. Vice versa, if the server does not send any keep-alives for 20 seconds, the client will disconnect and yield a "Timed out" exception.

The vanilla server uses a system-dependent time in milliseconds to generate the keep alive ID value.

clientbound.name: Ping (configuration)
clientbound.notes: Packet is not used by the vanilla server. When sent to the client, the client responds with a Pong packet with the same ID.

clientbound.name: Registry Data
clientbound.notes:
Represents certain registries that are sent from the server and are applied on the client.

See Java Edition protocol/Registry data for details.

fields.name: Data
fields.notes: Entry data.

fields.name: UUID
fields.notes: The UUID of the resource pack to be removed. If not present, every resource pack will be removed.

fields.name: UUID
fields.notes: The unique identifier of the resource pack.

fields.name: URL
fields.notes: The URL to the resource pack.

fields.name: Hash
fields.notes: A 40 character hexadecimal, case-insensitive SHA-1 hash of the resource pack file. If it's not a 40-character hexadecimal string, the client will not use it for hash verification and likely waste bandwidth.

fields.name: Forced
fields.notes: The vanilla client will be forced to use the resource pack from the server. If they decline, they will be kicked from the server.

fields.name: Prompt Message
fields.notes: This is shown in the prompt making the client accept or decline the resource pack (only if present).

clientbound.name: Store Cookie (configuration)
clientbound.notes: Stores some arbitrary data on the client, which persists between server transfers. The vanilla client only accepts cookies of up to 5 kiB in size.

fields.name: Key
fields.notes: The identifier of the cookie.

fields.name: Payload
fields.notes: The data of the cookie.

clientbound.name: Transfer (configuration)
clientbound.notes: Notifies the client that it should transfer to the given server. Cookies previously stored are preserved between server transfers.

fields.name: Host
fields.notes: The hostname or IP of the server.

fields.name: Port
fields.notes: The port of the server.

clientbound.name: Feature Flags
clientbound.notes:
Used to enable and disable features, generally experimental ones, on the client.

There is one special feature flag, which is in most versions:

clientbound.name: Update Tags (configuration)
clientbound.notes: Tag arrays look like:

fields.name: Array of tags
fields.type: ns.PrefixedArray[struct { Registry ns.Identifier; ArrayOfTag ns.Unknown // FIXME: See below }]
fields.notes: Prefixed Array

clientbound.name: Clientbound Known Packs
clientbound.notes:
Informs the client of which data packs are present on the server.
The client is expected to respond with its own Serverbound Known Packs packet.
The vanilla server does not continue with Configuration until it receives a response.

The vanilla client requires the minecraft:core pack with version 1.21.10 for a normal login sequence. This packet must be sent before the Registry Data packets.

fields.name: Known Packs
fields.type: ns.PrefixedArray[struct { Namespace ns.String; Id ns.String; Version ns.String }]
fields.notes: Prefixed Array

clientbound.name: Custom Report Details (configuration)
clientbound.notes: Contains a list of key-value text entries that are included in any crash or disconnection report generated during connection to the server.

fields.name: Details
fields.notes: Prefixed Array (32)

clientbound.name: Server Links (configuration)
clientbound.notes: This packet contains a list of links that the vanilla client will display in the menu available from the pause menu. Link labels can be built-in or custom (i.e., any text).

fields.name: Links
fields.type: ns.PrefixedArray[struct { Label ns.Or[ns.VarInt, ns.TextComponent]; Url ns.String }]
fields.notes: Prefixed Array

clientbound.name: Clear Dialog (configuration)
clientbound.notes: If we're currently in a dialog screen, then this removes the current screen and switches back to the previous one.

clientbound.name: Show Dialog (configuration)
clientbound.notes: Show a custom dialog screen to the client.

fields.name: Dialog
fields.notes: Inline definition as described at Java Edition protocol/Registry data#Dialog .

clientbound.name: Code of Conduct
clientbound.notes: Show the client the server Code of Conduct

fields.name: codeOfConduct
fields.notes: Code of Conduct of the server.

serverbound.name: Client Information (configuration)
serverbound.notes:
Sent when the player connects, or when settings are changed.

Displayed Skin Parts flags:

fields.name: Locale
fields.notes: e.g. en_GB .

fields.name: View Distance
fields.notes: Client-side render distance, in chunks.

fields.name: Chat Mode
fields.notes: 0: enabled, 1: commands only, 2: hidden. See Java Edition protocol/Chat#Client chat mode for more information.

fields.name: Chat Colors
fields.notes: “Colors” multiplayer setting. The vanilla server stores this value but does nothing with it (see MC-64867 ). Some third-party servers disable all coloring in chat and system messages when it is false.

fields.name: Displayed Skin Parts
fields.notes: Bit mask, see below.

fields.name: Main Hand
fields.notes: 0: Left, 1: Right.

fields.name: Enable text filtering
fields.notes: Enables filtering of text on signs and written book titles. The vanilla client sets this according to the profanityFilterPreferences.profanityFilterOn account attribute indicated by the Mojang API endpoint for player attributes . In offline mode, it is always false.

fields.name: Allow server listings
fields.notes: Servers usually list online players; this option should let you not show up in that list.

fields.name: Particle Status
fields.notes: 0: all, 1: decreased, 2: minimal

serverbound.name: Cookie Response (configuration)
serverbound.notes: Response to a Cookie Request (configuration) from the server. The vanilla server only accepts responses of up to 5 kiB in size.

fields.name: Key
fields.notes: The identifier of the cookie.

fields.name: Payload
fields.notes: The data of the cookie.

serverbound.name: Serverbound Plugin Message (configuration)
serverbound.notes:
Mods and plugins can use this to send their data. Minecraft itself uses some plugin channels . These internal channels are in the minecraft namespace.

More documentation on this: https://dinnerbone.com/blog/2012/01/13/minecraft-plugin-channels-messaging/

fields.name: Channel
fields.notes: Name of the plugin channel used to send the data.

fields.name: Data
fields.notes: Any data, depending on the channel. Typically this would be a sequence of fields using standard data types, but some unofficial channels have unusual formats. There is no length prefix that applies to all channel types, but the format specific to the channel may or may not include one or more length prefixes (such as the string length prefix in the standard minecraft:brand channel). The vanilla server enforces a length limit of 32767 bytes on this data, but only if the channel type is unrecognized.

serverbound.name: Acknowledge Finish Configuration
serverbound.notes:
Sent by the client to notify the server that the configuration process has finished. It is sent in response to the server's Finish Configuration .

This packet switches the connection state to play .

serverbound.name: Serverbound Keep Alive (configuration)
serverbound.notes: The server will frequently send out a keep-alive (see Clientbound Keep Alive ), each containing a random ID. The client must respond with the same packet.

serverbound.name: Pong (configuration)
serverbound.notes: Response to the clientbound packet ( Ping ) with the same id.

serverbound.name: Resource Pack Response (configuration)
serverbound.notes: Result can be one of the following values:

fields.name: UUID
fields.notes: The unique identifier of the resource pack received in the Add Resource Pack (configuration) request.

fields.name: Result
fields.notes: Result ID (see below).

serverbound.name: Serverbound Known Packs
serverbound.notes:
Informs the server of which data packs are present on the client. The client sends this in response to Clientbound Known Packs .

If the client specifies a pack in this packet, the server should omit its contained data from the Registry Data packet.

fields.name: Known Packs
fields.type: ns.PrefixedArray[struct { Namespace ns.String; Id ns.String; Version ns.String }]
fields.notes: Prefixed Array

serverbound.name: Custom Click Action (configuration)
serverbound.notes: Sent when the client clicks a Text Component with the minecraft:custom click action. This is meant as an alternative to running a command, but it will not have any effect on vanilla servers.

serverbound.name: Handshake
serverbound.notes: This packet causes the server to switch into the target state. It should be sent right after opening the TCP connection to prevent the server from disconnecting.

fields.name: Protocol Version
fields.notes: See protocol version numbers (currently 773 in Minecraft 1.21.10).

fields.name: Server Address
fields.notes: Hostname or IP, e.g. localhost or 127.0.0.1, that was used to connect. The vanilla server does not use this information. This is the name obtained after SRV record resolution, except in 1.17 (and no older or newer version) and during server list ping ( MC-278651 ), where it is the host portion of the address specified by the user directly. In 1.17.1 and later if a literal IP address is specified by the user, reverse DNS lookup is attempted, and the result is used as the value of this field if successful.

fields.name: Server Port
fields.notes: Default is 25565. The vanilla server does not use this information.

fields.name: Intent
fields.notes: 1 for Status , 2 for Login , 3 for Transfer .

fields.name: Reason
fields.notes: The reason why the player was disconnected.

clientbound.name: Encryption Request
clientbound.notes: See protocol encryption for details.

fields.name: Server ID
fields.notes: Always empty when sent by the vanilla server.

fields.name: Public Key
fields.notes: The server's public key, in bytes.

fields.name: Verify Token
fields.notes: A sequence of random bytes generated by the server.

fields.name: Should authenticate
fields.notes: Whether the client should attempt to authenticate through mojang servers .

clientbound.name: Set Compression
clientbound.notes: Enables compression. If compression is enabled, all following packets are encoded in the compressed packet format . Negative values will disable compression, meaning the packet format should remain in the uncompressed packet format . However, this packet is entirely optional, and if not sent, compression will also not be enabled (the vanilla server does not send the packet when compression is disabled).

fields.name: Threshold
fields.notes: Maximum size of a packet before it is compressed.

clientbound.name: Login Plugin Request
clientbound.notes:
Used to implement a custom handshaking flow together with Login Plugin Response .

Unlike plugin messages in "play" mode, these messages follow a lock-step request/response scheme, where the client is expected to respond to a request indicating whether it understood. The vanilla client always responds that it hasn't understood and sends an empty payload.

fields.name: Message ID
fields.notes: Generated by the server - should be unique to the connection.

fields.name: Channel
fields.notes: Name of the plugin channel used to send the data.

fields.name: Data
fields.notes: Any data, depending on the channel. Typically this would be a sequence of fields using standard data types, but some unofficial channels have unusual formats. There is no length prefix that applies to all channel types, but the format specific to the channel may or may not include one or more length prefixes (e.g. for strings). The vanilla client enforces a length limit of 1048576 bytes on this data, but only if the channel type is unrecognized (which is the case for all login plugin messages with a completely vanilla client).

clientbound.name: Cookie Request (login)
clientbound.notes: Requests a cookie that was previously stored.

fields.name: Key
fields.notes: The identifier of the cookie.

fields.name: Name
fields.notes: Player's Username.

fields.name: Player UUID
fields.notes: The UUID of the player logging in. Unused by the vanilla server.

serverbound.name: Encryption Response
serverbound.notes: See protocol encryption for details.

fields.name: Shared Secret
fields.notes: Shared Secret value, encrypted with the server's public key.

fields.name: Verify Token
fields.notes: Verify Token value, encrypted with the same public key as the shared secret.

fields.name: Message ID
fields.notes: Should match ID from server.

fields.name: Data
fields.notes: Any data, depending on the channel. Only present if the client understood the request. Typically this would be a sequence of fields using standard data types, but some unofficial channels have unusual formats. There is no length prefix that applies to all channel types, but the format specific to the channel may or may not include one or more length prefixes (e.g. for strings).

serverbound.name: Login Acknowledged
serverbound.notes:
Acknowledgement to the Login Success packet sent by the server.

This packet switches the connection state to configuration .

serverbound.name: Cookie Response (login)
serverbound.notes: Response to a Cookie Request (login) from the server. The vanilla server only accepts responses of up to 5 kiB in size.

fields.name: Key
fields.notes: The identifier of the cookie.

fields.name: Payload
fields.notes: The data of the cookie.

clientbound.name: Bundle Delimiter
clientbound.notes:
The delimiter for a bundle of packets. When received, the client should store every subsequent packet it receives and wait until another delimiter is received. Once that happens, the client is guaranteed to process every packet in the bundle on the same tick, and the client should stop storing packets.

As of 1.20.6, the vanilla server only uses this to ensure Spawn Entity and associated packets used to configure the entity happen on the same tick. Each entity gets a separate bundle.

The vanilla client doesn't allow more than 4096 packets in the same bundle.

clientbound.name: Spawn Entity
clientbound.notes:
Sent by the server to create an entity on the client, normally upon the entity spawning within or entering the player's view range.

The local player entity is automatically created by the client, and must not be created explicitly using this packet. Doing so on the vanilla client will have strange consequences.

fields.name: Entity ID
fields.notes: A unique integer ID mostly used in the protocol to identify the entity. If an entity with the same ID already exists on the client, it is automatically deleted and replaced by the new entity. On the vanilla server entity IDs are globally unique across all dimensions and never reused while the server is running, but not preserved across server restarts.

fields.name: Entity UUID
fields.notes: A unique identifier that is mostly used in persistence and places where the uniqueness matters more. It is possible to create multiple entities with the same UUID on the vanilla client, but a warning will be logged, and functionality dependent on UUIDs may ignore the entity or otherwise misbehave.

fields.name: Type
fields.notes: ID in the minecraft:entity_type registry (see "type" field in Java Edition protocol/Entity metadata#Entities ).

fields.name: Head Yaw
fields.notes: Only used by living entities, where the head of the entity may differ from the general body rotation.

fields.name: Data
fields.notes: Meaning dependent on the value of the Type field, see Java Edition protocol/Object data for details.

clientbound.name: Entity Animation
clientbound.notes:
Sent whenever an entity should change animation.

Animation can be one of the following values:

fields.name: Entity ID
fields.notes: Player ID.

fields.name: Animation
fields.notes: Animation ID (see below).

clientbound.name: Award Statistics
clientbound.notes:
Sent as a response to Client Status (id 1). Will only send the changed values if previously requested.

Categories (defined in the minecraft:stat_type registry).

fields.name: Statistics
fields.type: ns.PrefixedArray[struct { CategoryId ns.VarInt; StatisticId ns.VarInt; Value ns.VarInt }]
fields.notes: Prefixed Array

clientbound.name: Acknowledge Block Change
clientbound.notes: Acknowledges a user-initiated block change. After receiving this packet, the client will display the block state sent by the server instead of the one predicted by the client.

fields.name: Sequence ID
fields.notes: Represents the sequence to acknowledge; this is used for properly syncing block changes to the client after interactions.

clientbound.name: Set Block Destroy Stage
clientbound.notes:
0–9 are the displayable destroy stages and each other number means that there is no animation on this coordinate.

Block break animations can still be applied on air; the animation will remain visible, although there is no block being broken. However, if this is applied to a transparent block, odd graphical effects may happen, including water losing its transparency. (An effect similar to this can be seen in normal gameplay when breaking ice blocks)

If you need to display several break animations at the same time, you have to give each of them a unique Entity ID. The entity ID does not need to correspond to an actual entity on the client. It is valid to use a randomly generated number.

When removing the break animation, you must use the ID of the entity that set it.

fields.name: Entity ID
fields.notes: The ID of the entity breaking the block.

fields.name: Location
fields.notes: Block Position.

fields.name: Destroy Stage
fields.notes: 0–9 to set it, any other value to remove it.

clientbound.name: Block Entity Data
clientbound.notes: Sets the block entity associated with the block at the given location.

fields.name: Type
fields.notes: ID in the minecraft:block_entity_type registry

fields.name: NBT Data
fields.notes: Data to set.

fields.name: Location
fields.notes: Block coordinates.

fields.name: Action ID (Byte 1)
fields.notes: Varies depending on block — see Java Edition protocol/Block actions .

fields.name: Action Parameter (Byte 2)
fields.notes: Varies depending on block — see Java Edition protocol/Block actions .

fields.name: Block Type
fields.notes: ID in the minecraft:block registry. This value is unused by the vanilla client, as it will infer the type of block based on the given position.

fields.name: Location
fields.notes: Block Coordinates.

fields.name: Block ID
fields.notes: The new block state ID for the block as given in the block state registry .

fields.name: UUID
fields.notes: Unique ID for this bar.

fields.name: Action
fields.notes: Determines the layout of the remaining packet.

fields.name: Health
fields.notes: From 0 to 1. Values greater than 1 do not crash a vanilla client, and start rendering part of a second health bar at around 1.5.

fields.name: Color
fields.notes: Color ID (see below).

fields.name: Division
fields.notes: Type of division (see below).

fields.name: Flags
fields.notes: Bit mask. 0x01: should darken sky, 0x02: is dragon bar (used to play end music), 0x04: create fog (previously was also controlled by 0x02).

fields.name: Dividers
fields.notes: as above

clientbound.name: Change Difficulty
clientbound.notes: Changes the difficulty setting in the client's option menu

fields.name: Difficulty
fields.notes: 0: peaceful, 1: easy, 2: normal, 3: hard.

clientbound.name: Chunk Batch Finished
clientbound.notes:
Marks the end of a chunk batch. The vanilla client marks the time it receives this packet and calculates the elapsed duration since the beginning of the chunk batch . The server uses this duration and the batch size received in this packet to estimate the number of milliseconds elapsed per chunk received. This value is then used to calculate the desired number of chunks per tick through the formula 25 / millisPerChunk , which is reported to the server through Chunk Batch Received . This likely uses 25 instead of the normal tick duration of 50 so chunk processing will only use half of the client's and network's bandwidth.

The vanilla client uses the samples from the latest 15 batches to estimate the milliseconds per chunk number.

fields.name: Batch size
fields.notes: Number of chunks.

clientbound.name: Chunk Batch Start
clientbound.notes: Marks the start of a chunk batch. The vanilla client marks and stores the time it receives this packet.

clientbound.name: Chunk Biomes
clientbound.notes: Note: The order of X and Z is inverted, because the client reads them as one big-endian Long , with Z being the upper 32 bits.

fields.name: Chunk biome data
fields.type: ns.PrefixedArray[struct { ChunkZ ns.Int; ChunkX ns.Int; Data ns.PrefixedArray[ns.Byte] }]
fields.notes: Prefixed Array

clientbound.name: Clear Titles
clientbound.notes: Clear the client's current title information, with the option to also reset it.

clientbound.name: Command Suggestions Response
clientbound.notes: The server responds with a list of auto-completions of the last word sent to it. In the case of regular chat, this is a player username. Command names and parameters are also supported. The client sorts these alphabetically before listing them.

fields.name: ID
fields.notes: Transaction ID.

fields.name: Start
fields.notes: Start of the text to replace.

fields.name: Length
fields.notes: Length of the text to replace.

fields.name: Tooltip
fields.notes: Tooltip to display.

clientbound.name: Commands
clientbound.notes:
Lists all of the commands on the server, and how they are parsed.

This is a directed graph, with one root node. Each redirect or child node must refer only to nodes that have already been declared.

For more information on this packet, see the Java Edition protocol/Command data article.

fields.name: Nodes
fields.notes: An array of nodes.

fields.name: Root index
fields.notes: Index of the root node in the previous array.

clientbound.name: Close Container
clientbound.notes: This packet is sent from the server to the client when a window is forcibly closed, such as when a chest is destroyed while it's open. The vanilla client disregards the provided window ID and closes any active window.

fields.name: Window ID
fields.notes: This is the ID of the window that was closed. 0 for inventory.

clientbound.name: Set Container Content
clientbound.notes:
Replaces the contents of a container window. Sent by the server upon initialization of a container window or the player's inventory, and in response to state ID mismatches (see #Click Container ).

See inventory windows for further information about how slots are indexed.
Use Open Screen to open the container on the client.

fields.name: Window ID
fields.notes: The ID of window which items are being sent for. 0 for player inventory. The client ignores any packets targeting a Window ID other than the current one. However, an exception is made for the player inventory, which may be targeted at any time. (The vanilla server does not appear to utilize this special case.)

fields.name: State ID
fields.notes: A server-managed sequence number used to avoid desynchronization; see #Click Container .

fields.name: Carried Item
fields.notes: Item being dragged with the mouse.

clientbound.name: Set Container Property
clientbound.notes:
This packet is used to inform the client that part of a GUI window should be updated.

The meaning of the Property field depends on the type of the window. The following table shows the known combinations of window type and property, and how the value is to be interpreted.

fields.name: Property
fields.notes: The property to be updated, see below.

fields.name: Value
fields.notes: The new value for the property, see below.

clientbound.name: Set Container Slot
clientbound.notes:
Sent by the server when an item in a slot (in a window) is added/removed.

If Window ID is 0, the hotbar and offhand slots (slots 36 through 45) may be updated even when a different container window is open. (The vanilla server does not appear to utilize this special case.) Updates are also restricted to those slots when the player is looking at a creative inventory tab other than the survival inventory. (The vanilla server does not handle this restriction in any way, leading to MC-242392 .)

When a container window is open, the server never sends updates targeting Window ID 0—all of the window types include slots for the player inventory. The client must automatically apply changes targeting the inventory portion of a container window to the main inventory; the server does not resend them for ID 0 when the window is closed. However, since the armor and offhand slots are only present on ID 0, updates to those slots occurring while a window is open must be deferred by the server until the window's closure.

fields.name: Window ID
fields.notes: The window that is being updated. 0 for player inventory. The client ignores any packets targeting a Window ID other than the current one; see below for exceptions.

fields.name: State ID
fields.notes: A server-managed sequence number used to avoid desynchronization; see #Click Container .

fields.name: Slot
fields.notes: The slot that should be updated.

clientbound.name: Cookie Request (play)
clientbound.notes: Requests a cookie that was previously stored.

fields.name: Key
fields.notes: The identifier of the cookie.

clientbound.name: Set Cooldown
clientbound.notes: Applies a cooldown period to all items with the given type. Used by the vanilla server with enderpearls. This packet should be sent when the cooldown starts and also when the cooldown ends (to compensate for lag), although the client will end the cooldown automatically. Can be applied to any item, note that interactions still get sent to the server with the item, but the client does not play the animation nor attempt to predict results (i.e, block placing).

fields.name: Cooldown Group
fields.notes: Identifier of the item (minecraft:stone) or the cooldown group ("use_cooldown" item component)

fields.name: Cooldown Ticks
fields.notes: Number of ticks to apply a cooldown for, or 0 to clear the cooldown.

clientbound.name: Chat Suggestions
clientbound.notes: Unused by the vanilla server. Likely provided for custom servers to send chat message completions to clients.

fields.name: Action
fields.notes: 0: Add, 1: Remove, 2: Set

clientbound.name: Clientbound Plugin Message (play)
clientbound.notes:
Mods and plugins can use this to send their data. Minecraft itself uses several plugin channels . These internal channels are in the minecraft namespace.

More information on how it works on Dinnerbone's blog . More documentation about internal and popular registered channels is here .

fields.name: Channel
fields.notes: Name of the plugin channel used to send the data.

fields.name: Data
fields.notes: Any data, depending on the channel. Typically this would be a sequence of fields using standard data types, but some unofficial channels have unusual formats. There is no length prefix that applies to all channel types, but the format specific to the channel may or may not include one or more length prefixes (such as the string length prefix in the standard minecraft:brand channel). The vanilla client enforces a length limit of 1048576 bytes on this data, but only if the channel type is unrecognized.

fields.name: Entity ID
fields.notes: The ID of the entity taking damage

fields.name: Source Type ID
fields.notes: The type of damage in the minecraft:damage_type registry, defined by the Registry Data packet.

fields.name: Source Cause ID
fields.notes: The ID + 1 of the entity responsible for the damage, if present. If not present, the value is 0

fields.name: Source Direct ID
fields.notes: The ID + 1 of the entity that directly dealt the damage, if present. If not present, the value is 0. If this field is present: and damage was dealt indirectly, such as by the use of a projectile, this field will contain the ID of such projectile; and damage was dealt directly, such as by manually attacking, this field will contain the same value as Source Cause ID.

clientbound.name: Debug Chunk Value
clientbound.notes: Note: The order of X and Z is inverted, because the client reads them as one big-endian Long , with Z being the upper 32 bits.

clientbound.name: Debug Sample
clientbound.notes:
Sample data that is sent periodically after the client has subscribed with Debug Sample Subscription .

The vanilla server only sends debug samples to players who are server operators.

Types:

fields.name: Sample
fields.notes: Array of type-dependent samples.

fields.name: Sample Type
fields.notes: See below.

clientbound.name: Delete Message
clientbound.notes: Removes a message from the client's chat. This only works for messages with signatures; system messages cannot be deleted with this packet.

fields.name: Message ID
fields.notes: The message ID + 1, used for validating message signature. The next field is present only when value of this field is equal to 0.

fields.name: Signature
fields.notes: The previous message's signature. Always 256 bytes and not length-prefixed.

clientbound.name: Disconnect (play)
clientbound.notes: Sent by the server before it disconnects a client. The client assumes that the server has already closed the connection by the time the packet arrives.

fields.name: Reason
fields.notes: Displayed to the client when the connection terminates.

clientbound.name: Disguised Chat Message
clientbound.notes:
Sends the client a chat message, but without any message signing information.

The vanilla server uses this packet when the console is communicating with players through commands, such as /say , /tell , /me , among others.

fields.name: Message
fields.notes: This is used as the content parameter when formatting the message on the client.

fields.name: Chat Type
fields.notes: Either the type of chat in the minecraft:chat_type registry, defined by the Registry Data packet, or an inline definition.

fields.name: Sender Name
fields.notes: The name of the one sending the message, usually the sender's display name. This is used as the sender parameter when formatting the message on the client.

fields.name: Target Name
fields.notes: The name of the one receiving the message, usually the receiver's display name. This is used as the target parameter when formatting the message on the client.

clientbound.name: Entity Event
clientbound.notes: Entity statuses generally trigger an animation for an entity. The available statuses vary by the entity's type (and are available to subclasses of that type as well).

fields.name: Entity Status
fields.notes: See Java Edition protocol/Entity statuses for a list of which statuses are valid for each type of entity.

clientbound.name: Teleport Entity
clientbound.notes: This packet is sent by the server when an entity moves more than 8 blocks.

fields.name: Yaw
fields.notes: Rotation on the X axis, in degrees.

fields.name: Pitch
fields.notes: Rotation on the Y axis, in degrees.

clientbound.name: Explosion
clientbound.notes: Sent when an explosion occurs (creepers, TNT, and ghast fireballs).

fields.name: Explosion Particle ID
fields.notes: ID in the minecraft:particle_type registry.

fields.name: Explosion Particle Data
fields.notes: Particle data as specified in Java Edition protocol/Particles .

fields.name: Explosion Sound
fields.notes: ID in the minecraft:sound_event registry, or an inline definition.

fields.name: Particle Data
fields.notes: Particle data as specified in Java Edition protocol/Particles .

clientbound.name: Unload Chunk
clientbound.notes:
Tells the client to unload a chunk column.

Note: The order is inverted, because the client reads this packet as one big-endian Long , with Z being the upper 32 bits.

It is legal to send this packet even if the given chunk is not currently loaded.

fields.name: Chunk Z
fields.notes: Block coordinate divided by 16, rounded down.

fields.name: Chunk X
fields.notes: Block coordinate divided by 16, rounded down.

clientbound.name: Game Event
clientbound.notes:
Used for a wide variety of game events, such as weather, respawn availability (from bed and respawn anchor ), game mode, some game rules, and demo messages.

Events :

fields.name: Event
fields.notes: See below.

fields.name: Value
fields.notes: Depends on Event.

clientbound.name: Open Horse Screen
clientbound.notes: This packet is used exclusively for opening the horse GUI. Open Screen is used for all other GUIs. The client will not open the inventory if the Entity ID does not point to a horse-like animal.

fields.name: Window ID
fields.notes: Same as the field of Open Screen .

fields.name: Inventory columns count
fields.notes: How many columns of horse inventory slots exist in the GUI, 3 slots per column.

fields.name: Entity ID
fields.notes: The "owner" entity of the GUI. The client should close the GUI if the owner entity dies or is cleared.

clientbound.name: Hurt Animation
clientbound.notes: Plays a bobbing animation for the entity receiving damage.

fields.name: Entity ID
fields.notes: The ID of the entity taking damage

fields.name: Yaw
fields.notes: The direction the damage is coming from in relation to the entity

clientbound.name: Initialize World Border
clientbound.notes: The vanilla client determines how solid to display the warning by comparing to whichever is higher, the warning distance or whichever is lower, the distance from the current diameter to the target diameter or the place the border will be after warningTime seconds. In pseudocode:

fields.name: Old Diameter
fields.notes: Current length of a single side of the world border, in meters.

fields.name: New Diameter
fields.notes: Target length of a single side of the world border, in meters.

fields.name: Speed
fields.notes: Number of real-time milli seconds until New Diameter is reached. It appears that vanilla server does not sync world border speed to game ticks, so it gets out of sync with server lag. If the world border is not moving, this is set to 0.

fields.name: Portal Teleport Boundary
fields.notes: Resulting coordinates from a portal teleport are limited to ±value. Usually 29999984.

fields.name: Warning Blocks
fields.notes: In meters.

fields.name: Warning Time
fields.notes: In seconds as set by /worldborder warning time .

clientbound.name: Clientbound Keep Alive (play)
clientbound.notes:
The server will frequently send out a keep-alive, each containing a random ID. The client must respond with the same payload (see Serverbound Keep Alive ). If the client does not respond to a Keep Alive packet within 15 seconds after it was sent, the server kicks the client. Vice versa, if the server does not send any keep-alives for 20 seconds, the client will disconnect and yield a "Timed out" exception.

The vanilla server uses a system-dependent time in milliseconds to generate the keep alive ID value.

clientbound.name: Chunk Data and Update Light
clientbound.notes:
Sent when a chunk comes into the client's view distance, specifying its terrain, lighting and block entities.

The chunk must be within the view area previously specified with Set Center Chunk ; see that packet for details.

It is not strictly necessary to send all block entities in this packet; it is still legal to send them with Block Entity Data later.

Unlike the Update Light packet, which uses the same format, setting the bit corresponding to a section to 0 in both of the block light or sky light masks does not appear to be useful, and the results in testing have been highly inconsistent.

fields.name: Chunk X
fields.notes: Chunk coordinate (block coordinate divided by 16, rounded down)

fields.name: Chunk Z
fields.notes: Chunk coordinate (block coordinate divided by 16, rounded down)

clientbound.name: World Event
clientbound.notes:
Sent when a client is to play a sound or particle effect.

By default, the Minecraft client adjusts the volume of sound effects based on distance. The final boolean field is used to disable this, and instead, the effect is played from 2 blocks away in the correct direction. Currently, this is only used for effect 1023 (wither spawn), effect 1028 (enderdragon death), and effect 1038 (end portal opening); it is ignored on other effects.

Events:

fields.name: Event
fields.notes: The event, see below.

fields.name: Location
fields.notes: The location of the event.

fields.name: Data
fields.notes: Extra data for certain events, see below.

fields.name: Disable Relative Volume
fields.notes: See above.

clientbound.name: Particle
clientbound.notes: Displays the named particle

fields.name: Long Distance
fields.notes: If true, particle distance increases from 256 to 65536.

fields.name: Always Visible
fields.notes: Whether this particle should always be visible.

fields.name: X
fields.notes: X position of the particle.

fields.name: Y
fields.notes: Y position of the particle.

fields.name: Z
fields.notes: Z position of the particle.

fields.name: Offset X
fields.notes: This is added to the X position after being multiplied by random.nextGaussian() .

fields.name: Offset Y
fields.notes: This is added to the Y position after being multiplied by random.nextGaussian() .

fields.name: Offset Z
fields.notes: This is added to the Z position after being multiplied by random.nextGaussian() .

fields.name: Particle Count
fields.notes: The number of particles to create.

fields.name: Particle ID
fields.notes: ID in the minecraft:particle_type registry.

fields.name: Data
fields.notes: Particle data as specified in Java Edition protocol/Particles .

clientbound.name: Update Light
clientbound.notes:
Updates light levels for a chunk. See Light for information on how lighting works in Minecraft.

A bit will never be set in both the block light mask and the empty block light mask, though it may be present in neither of them (if the block light does not need to be updated for the corresponding chunk section). The same applies to the sky light mask and the empty sky light mask.

fields.name: Chunk X
fields.notes: Chunk coordinate (block coordinate divided by 16, rounded down)

fields.name: Chunk Z
fields.notes: Chunk coordinate (block coordinate divided by 16, rounded down)

clientbound.name: Login (play)
clientbound.notes: See protocol encryption for information on logging in.

fields.name: Entity ID
fields.notes: The player's Entity ID (EID).

fields.name: Dimension Names
fields.notes: Identifiers for all dimensions on the server.

fields.name: Max Players
fields.notes: Was once used by the client to draw the tab list, but now it is ignored.

fields.name: View Distance
fields.notes: Render distance (2-32).

fields.name: Simulation Distance
fields.notes: The distance that the client will process specific things, such as entities.

fields.name: Reduced Debug Info
fields.notes: If true, a vanilla client shows reduced information on the debug screen . For servers in development, this should almost always be false.

fields.name: Enable respawn screen
fields.notes: Set to false when the doImmediateRespawn gamerule is true.

fields.name: Do limited crafting
fields.notes: Whether players can only craft recipes they have already unlocked. Currently unused by the client.

fields.name: Dimension Type
fields.notes: The ID of the type of dimension in the minecraft:dimension_type registry, defined by the Registry Data packet.

fields.name: Dimension Name
fields.notes: Name of the dimension being spawned into.

fields.name: Hashed seed
fields.notes: First 8 bytes of the SHA-256 hash of the world's seed. Used client-side for biome noise

fields.name: Game mode
fields.notes: 0: Survival, 1: Creative, 2: Adventure, 3: Spectator.

fields.name: Previous Game mode
fields.notes: -1: Undefined (null), 0: Survival, 1: Creative, 2: Adventure, 3: Spectator. The previous game mode. Vanilla client uses this for the debug (F3 + N & F3 + F4) game mode switch. (More information needed)

fields.name: Is Debug
fields.notes: True if the world is a debug mode world; debug mode worlds cannot be modified and have predefined blocks.

fields.name: Is Flat
fields.notes: True if the world is a superflat world; flat worlds have different void fog and a horizon at y=0 instead of y=63.

fields.name: Has death location
fields.notes: If true, then the next two fields are present.

fields.name: Death dimension name
fields.notes: Name of the dimension the player died in.

fields.name: Death location
fields.notes: The location that the player died at.

fields.name: Portal cooldown
fields.notes: The number of ticks until the player can use the last used portal again. Looks like it's an attempt to fix MC-180.

clientbound.name: Map Data
clientbound.notes:
Updates a rectangular area on a map item.

For icons, a direction of 0 is a vertical icon and increments by 22.5° (360/16).

Types are based off of rows and columns in map_icons.png :

fields.name: Map ID
fields.notes: Map ID of the map being modified

fields.name: Scale
fields.notes: From 0 for a fully zoomed-in map (1 block per pixel) to 4 for a fully zoomed-out map (16 blocks per pixel)

fields.name: Locked
fields.notes: True if the map has been locked in a cartography table

fields.name: X
fields.notes: Map coordinates: -128 for furthest left, +127 for furthest right

fields.name: Z
fields.notes: Map coordinates: -128 for highest, +127 for lowest

fields.name: Rows
fields.notes: Only if Columns is more than 0; number of rows updated

fields.name: X
fields.notes: Only if Columns is more than 0; x offset of the westernmost column

fields.name: Z
fields.notes: Only if Columns is more than 0; z offset of the northernmost row

fields.name: Data
fields.notes: Only if Columns is more than 0; see Map item format

clientbound.name: Merchant Offers
clientbound.notes:
The list of trades a villager NPC is offering.

Trade Item:

fields.name: Window ID
fields.notes: The ID of the window that is open; this is an int rather than a byte.

fields.name: Output item
fields.notes: The item the player will receive from this villager trade.

fields.name: Input item 2
fields.notes: The second item the player has to supply for this villager trade.

fields.name: Trade disabled
fields.notes: True if the trade is disabled; false if the trade is enabled.

fields.name: Number of trade uses
fields.notes: Number of times the trade has been used so far. If equal to the maximum number of trades, the client will display a red X.

fields.name: Maximum number of trade uses
fields.notes: Number of times this trade can be used before it's exhausted.

fields.name: XP
fields.notes: Amount of XP the villager will earn each time the trade is used.

fields.name: Special Price
fields.notes: Can be zero or negative. The number is added to the price when an item is discounted due to player reputation or other effects.

fields.name: Price Multiplier
fields.notes: Can be low (0.05) or high (0.2). Determines how much demand, player reputation, and temporary effects will adjust the price.

fields.name: Demand
fields.notes: If positive, causes the price to increase. Negative values seem to be treated the same as zero.

fields.name: Villager level
fields.notes: Appears on the trade GUI; meaning comes from the translation key merchant.level. + level. 1: Novice, 2: Apprentice, 3: Journeyman, 4: Expert, 5: Master.

fields.name: Experience
fields.notes: Total experience for this villager (always 0 for the wandering trader).

fields.name: Is regular villager
fields.notes: True if this is a regular villager; false for the wandering trader. When false, hides the villager level and some other GUI elements.

fields.name: Can restock
fields.notes: True for regular villagers and false for the wandering trader. If true, the "Villagers restock up to two times per day." message is displayed when hovering over disabled trades.

clientbound.name: Update Entity Position
clientbound.notes: This packet is sent by the server when an entity moves a small distance. The change in position is represented as a fixed-point number with 12 fraction bits and 4 integer bits. As such, the maximum movement distance along each axis is 8 blocks in the negative direction, or 7.999755859375 blocks in the positive direction. If the movement exceeds these limits, Teleport Entity should be sent instead.

fields.name: Delta X
fields.notes: Change in X position as currentX * 4096 - prevX * 4096 .

fields.name: Delta Y
fields.notes: Change in Y position as currentY * 4096 - prevY * 4096 .

fields.name: Delta Z
fields.notes: Change in Z position as currentZ * 4096 - prevZ * 4096 .

clientbound.name: Update Entity Position and Rotation
clientbound.notes: This packet is sent by the server when an entity rotates and moves. See #Update Entity Position for how the position is encoded.

fields.name: Delta X
fields.notes: Change in X position as currentX * 4096 - prevX * 4096 .

fields.name: Delta Y
fields.notes: Change in Y position as currentY * 4096 - prevY * 4096 .

fields.name: Delta Z
fields.notes: Change in Z position as currentZ * 4096 - prevZ * 4096 .

fields.name: Yaw
fields.notes: New angle, not a delta.

fields.name: Pitch
fields.notes: New angle, not a delta.

clientbound.name: Update Entity Rotation
clientbound.notes: This packet is sent by the server when an entity rotates.

fields.name: Yaw
fields.notes: New angle, not a delta.

fields.name: Pitch
fields.notes: New angle, not a delta.

clientbound.name: Move Vehicle (clientbound)
clientbound.notes: If the player is riding a client-side-controlled vehicle, teleports the vehicle to the specified position. Sent by the vanilla server in response to serverbound Move Vehicle packets that fail the movement speed check. Note that all fields use absolute positioning and do not allow for relative positioning.

fields.name: X
fields.notes: Absolute position (X coordinate).

fields.name: Y
fields.notes: Absolute position (Y coordinate).

fields.name: Z
fields.notes: Absolute position (Z coordinate).

fields.name: Yaw
fields.notes: Absolute rotation on the vertical axis, in degrees.

fields.name: Pitch
fields.notes: Absolute rotation on the horizontal axis, in degrees.

clientbound.name: Open Book
clientbound.notes: Sent when a player right-clicks with a signed book. This tells the client to open the book GUI.

fields.name: Hand
fields.notes: 0: Main hand, 1: Off hand .

clientbound.name: Open Screen
clientbound.notes:
This is sent to the client when it should open an inventory, such as a chest, workbench, furnace, or other container. Resending this packet with the already existing window ID, will update the window title and window type without closing the window.

This message is not sent to clients opening their own inventory, nor do clients inform the server in any way when doing so. From the server's perspective, the inventory is always "open" whenever no other windows are.

For horses, use Open Horse Screen .

fields.name: Window ID
fields.notes: An identifier for the window to be displayed. The vanilla server implementation is a counter, starting at 1. There can only be one window at a time; this is only used to ignore outdated packets targeting already-closed windows. Note also that the Window ID field in most other packets is only a single byte, and indeed, the vanilla server wraps around after 100.

fields.name: Window Type
fields.notes: The window type to use for display. Contained in the minecraft:menu registry; see Java Edition protocol/Inventory for the different values.

fields.name: Window Title
fields.notes: The title of the window.

clientbound.name: Open Sign Editor
clientbound.notes: Sent when the client has placed a sign and is allowed to send Update Sign . There must already be a sign at the given location (which the client does not do automatically) - send a Block Update first.

fields.name: Is Front Text
fields.notes: Whether the opened editor is for the front or on the back of the sign

clientbound.name: Ping (play)
clientbound.notes:
Packet is not used by the vanilla server. When sent to the client, client responds with a Pong packet with the same ID.

Unlike Keep Alive this packet is handled synchronously with game logic on the vanilla client, and can thus be used to reliably detect which serverbound packets were sent after the ping and all preceding clientbound packets were received and handled.

fields.name: Payload
fields.notes: Should be the same as sent by the client.

clientbound.name: Place Ghost Recipe
clientbound.notes: Response to the serverbound packet ( Place Recipe ), with the same recipe ID. Appears to be used to notify the UI.

clientbound.name: Player Abilities (clientbound)
clientbound.notes:
The latter 2 floats are used to indicate the flying speed and field of view respectively, while the first byte is used to determine the value of 4 booleans.

About the flags:

fields.name: Flags
fields.notes: Bit field, see below.

fields.name: Flying Speed
fields.notes: 0.05 by default.

fields.name: Field of View Modifier
fields.notes: Modifies the field of view, like a speed potion. A vanilla server will use the same value as the movement speed sent in the Update Attributes packet, which defaults to 0.1 for players.

clientbound.name: Player Chat Message
clientbound.notes:
Sends the client a chat message from a player.

Currently, a lot is unknown about this packet, blank descriptions are for those that are unknown

fields.name: Header
fields.notes: VarInt

fields.name: Sender
fields.notes: Used by the vanilla client for the disableChat launch option. Setting both longs to 0 will always display the message regardless of the setting.

fields.name: Message Signature bytes
fields.notes: Cryptography, the signature consists of the Sender UUID, Session UUID from the Player Session packet, Index, Salt, Timestamp in epoch seconds, the length of the original chat content, the original content itself, the length of Previous Messages, and all of the Previous message signatures. These values are hashed with SHA-256 and signed using the RSA cryptosystem. Modifying any of these values in the packet will cause this signature to fail. This buffer is always 256 bytes long and it is not length-prefixed.

fields.name: Timestamp
fields.notes: Represents the time the message was signed as milliseconds since the epoch , used to check if the message was received within 2 minutes of it being sent.

fields.name: Salt
fields.notes: Cryptography, used for validating the message signature.

fields.name: Signature
fields.notes: The previous message's signature. Contains the same type of data as Message Signature bytes (256 bytes) above. Not length-prefixed.

fields.name: Filter Type
fields.notes: If the message has been filtered

fields.name: Filter Type Bits
fields.notes: Only present if the Filter Type is Partially Filtered. Specifies the indices at which characters in the original message string should be replaced with the # symbol (i.e., filtered) by the vanilla client

fields.name: Sender Name
fields.notes: The name of the one sending the message, usually the sender's display name. This is used as the sender parameter when formatting the message on the client.

fields.name: Target Name
fields.notes: The name of the one receiving the message, usually the receiver's display name. This is used as the target parameter when formatting the message on the client.

clientbound.name: End Combat
clientbound.notes: Unused by the vanilla client. This data was once used for twitch.tv metadata circa 1.8.

fields.name: Duration
fields.notes: Length of the combat in ticks.

clientbound.name: Enter Combat
clientbound.notes: Unused by the vanilla client. This data was once used for twitch.tv metadata circa 1.8.

clientbound.name: Combat Death
clientbound.notes: Used to send a respawn screen.

fields.name: Player ID
fields.notes: Entity ID of the player that died (should match the client's entity ID).

fields.name: Message
fields.notes: The death message.

clientbound.name: Player Info Remove
clientbound.notes: Sent by the server to remove players from the client's player list.

fields.name: UUIDs
fields.notes: UUIDs of players to remove.

fields.name: Actions
fields.notes: Determines what actions are present.

fields.name: Player Actions
fields.notes: The length of this array is determined by the number of Player Actions that give a non-zero value when applying its mask to the actions flag. For example, given the decimal number 5, binary 00000101. The masks 0x01 and 0x04 would return a non-zero value, meaning the Player Actions array would include two actions: Add Player and Update Game Mode.

clientbound.name: Look At
clientbound.notes:
Used to rotate the client player to face the given location or entity (for /teleport [<targets>] <x> <y> <z> facing ).

If the entity given by entity ID cannot be found, this packet should be treated as if is entity was false.

fields.name: Feet/eyes
fields.notes: Values are feet=0, eyes=1. If set to eyes, aims using the head position; otherwise, aims using the feet position.

fields.name: Target x
fields.notes: x coordinate of the point to face towards.

fields.name: Target y
fields.notes: y coordinate of the point to face towards.

fields.name: Target z
fields.notes: z coordinate of the point to face towards.

fields.name: Is entity
fields.notes: If true, additional information about an entity is provided.

fields.name: Entity ID
fields.notes: Only if is entity is true — the entity to face towards.

fields.name: Entity feet/eyes
fields.notes: Whether to look at the entity's eyes or feet. Same values and meanings as before, just for the entity's head/feet.

clientbound.name: Synchronize Player Position
clientbound.notes:
Teleports the client, e.g., during login, when using an ender pearl, in response to invalid move packets, etc.

Due to latency, the server may receive outdated movement packets sent before the client was aware of the teleport. To account for this, the server ignores all movement packets from the client until a Confirm Teleportation packet with an ID matching the one sent in the teleport packet is received. The vanilla client will also send a Set Player Position and Rotation packet after the Confirm Teleportation packet with the position and rotation received from this packet, and horizontal collision and on ground set to false.

Yaw is measured in degrees and does not follow classical trigonometry rules. The unit circle of yaw on the XZ-plane starts at (0, 1) and turns counterclockwise, with 90 at (-1, 0), 180 at (0, -1) and 270 at (1, 0). Additionally, yaw is not clamped to between 0 and 360 degrees; any number is valid, including negative numbers and numbers greater than 360 (see MC-90097 ).

Pitch is measured in degrees, where 0 is looking straight ahead, -90 is looking straight up, and 90 is looking straight down.

If the player is riding a vehicle, this packet has no effect, but both the Confirm Teleportation and Set Player Position and Rotation packets are still sent.

fields.name: Teleport ID
fields.notes: Client should confirm this packet with Confirm Teleportation containing the same Teleport ID.

fields.name: X
fields.notes: Absolute or relative position, depending on Flags.

fields.name: Y
fields.notes: Absolute or relative position, depending on Flags.

fields.name: Z
fields.notes: Absolute or relative position, depending on Flags.

fields.name: Yaw
fields.notes: Absolute or relative rotation on the X axis, in degrees.

fields.name: Pitch
fields.notes: Absolute or relative rotation on the Y axis, in degrees.

fields.name: Yaw
fields.notes: Rotation on the X axis, in degrees.

fields.name: Pitch
fields.notes: Rotation on the Y axis, in degrees.

fields.name: Recipes
fields.type: ns.PrefixedArray[struct { RecipeId ns.VarInt; Display ns.RecipeDisplay; GroupId ns.VarInt; CategoryId ns.VarInt; Ingredients ns.PrefixedOptional[ns.PrefixedIDArraySet]; Flags ns.Byte }]
fields.notes: Prefixed Array

fields.name: Replace
fields.notes: Replace or Add to known recipes

fields.name: Recipes
fields.notes: IDs of recipes to remove.

fields.name: Crafting Recipe Book Open
fields.notes: If true, then the crafting recipe book will be open when the player opens its inventory.

fields.name: Crafting Recipe Book Filter Active
fields.notes: If true, then the filtering option is active when the player opens its inventory.

fields.name: Smelting Recipe Book Open
fields.notes: If true, then the smelting recipe book will be open when the player opens its inventory.

fields.name: Smelting Recipe Book Filter Active
fields.notes: If true, then the filtering option is active when the player opens its inventory.

fields.name: Blast Furnace Recipe Book Open
fields.notes: If true, then the blast furnace recipe book will be open when the player opens its inventory.

fields.name: Blast Furnace Recipe Book Filter Active
fields.notes: If true, then the filtering option is active when the player opens its inventory.

fields.name: Smoker Recipe Book Open
fields.notes: If true, then the smoker recipe book will be open when the player opens its inventory.

fields.name: Smoker Recipe Book Filter Active
fields.notes: If true, then the filtering option is active when the player opens its inventory.

clientbound.name: Remove Entities
clientbound.notes: Sent by the server when an entity is to be destroyed on the client.

fields.name: Entity IDs
fields.notes: The list of entities to destroy.

fields.name: Effect ID
fields.notes: See this table .

clientbound.name: Reset Score
clientbound.notes: This is sent to the client when it should remove a scoreboard item.

fields.name: Entity Name
fields.notes: The entity whose score this is. For players, this is their username; for other entities, it is their UUID.

fields.name: Objective Name
fields.notes: The name of the objective the score belongs to.

fields.name: UUID
fields.notes: The UUID of the resource pack to be removed.

fields.name: UUID
fields.notes: The unique identifier of the resource pack.

fields.name: URL
fields.notes: The URL to the resource pack.

fields.name: Hash
fields.notes: A 40 character hexadecimal, case-insensitive SHA-1 hash of the resource pack file. If it's not a 40-character hexadecimal string, the client will not use it for hash verification and likely waste bandwidth.

fields.name: Forced
fields.notes: The vanilla client will be forced to use the resource pack from the server. If they decline, they will be kicked from the server.

fields.name: Prompt Message
fields.notes: This is shown in the prompt making the client accept or decline the resource pack.

clientbound.name: Respawn
clientbound.notes:
To change the player's dimension (overworld/nether/end), send them a respawn packet with the appropriate dimension, followed by prechunks/chunks for the new dimension, and finally a position and look packet. You do not need to unload chunks; the client will do it automatically.

The background of the loading screen is determined based on the Dimension Name specified in this packet and the one specified in the previous Login or Respawn packet. If either the current or the previous dimension is minecraft:nether , the Nether portal background is used. Otherwise, if the current or the previous dimension is minecraft:the_end , the End portal background is used. If the player is dead (health is 0), the default background is always used.

fields.name: Dimension Type
fields.notes: The ID of type of dimension in the minecraft:dimension_type registry, defined by the Registry Data packet.

fields.name: Dimension Name
fields.notes: Name of the dimension being spawned into.

fields.name: Hashed seed
fields.notes: First 8 bytes of the SHA-256 hash of the world's seed. Used client-side for biome noise

fields.name: Game mode
fields.notes: 0: Survival, 1: Creative, 2: Adventure, 3: Spectator.

fields.name: Previous Game mode
fields.notes: -1: Undefined (null), 0: Survival, 1: Creative, 2: Adventure, 3: Spectator. The previous game mode. Vanilla client uses this for the debug (F3 + N & F3 + F4) game mode switch. (More information needed)

fields.name: Is Debug
fields.notes: True if the world is a debug mode world; debug mode worlds cannot be modified and have predefined blocks.

fields.name: Is Flat
fields.notes: True if the world is a superflat world; flat worlds have different void fog and a horizon at y=0 instead of y=63.

fields.name: Has death location
fields.notes: If true, then the next two fields are present.

fields.name: Death dimension Name
fields.notes: Name of the dimension the player died in.

fields.name: Death location
fields.notes: The location that the player died at.

fields.name: Portal cooldown
fields.notes: The number of ticks until the player can use the portal again.

fields.name: Data kept
fields.notes: Bit mask. 0x01: Keep attributes, 0x02: Keep metadata. Tells which data should be kept on the client side once the player has respawned. In the vanilla implementation, this is context-dependent: normal respawns (after death) keep no data; exiting the end poem/credits keeps the attributes; other dimension changes (portals or teleports) keep all data.

clientbound.name: Set Head Rotation
clientbound.notes:
Changes the direction an entity's head is facing.

While sending the Entity Look packet changes the vertical rotation of the head, sending this packet appears to be necessary to rotate the head horizontally.

fields.name: Head Yaw
fields.notes: New angle, not a delta.

clientbound.name: Update Section Blocks
clientbound.notes: Chunk section position is encoded:

fields.name: Chunk section position
fields.notes: Chunk section coordinate (encoded chunk x and z with each 22 bits, and section y with 20 bits, from left to right).

fields.name: Blocks
fields.notes: Each entry is composed of the block state id, shifted left by 12, and the relative block position in the chunk section (4 bits for x, z, and y, from left to right).

clientbound.name: Select Advancements Tab
clientbound.notes:
Sent by the server to indicate that the client should switch advancement tab. Sent either when the client switches tab in the GUI or when an advancement is made in another tab.

The Identifier must be one of the following if no custom data pack is loaded:

fields.name: Identifier
fields.notes: See below.

fields.name: Icon
fields.notes: Icon bytes in the PNG format.

clientbound.name: Set Action Bar Text
clientbound.notes: Displays a message above the hotbar. Equivalent to System Chat Message with Overlay set to true, except that chat message blocking isn't performed. Used by the vanilla server only to implement the /title command.

fields.name: Old Diameter
fields.notes: Current length of a single side of the world border, in meters.

fields.name: New Diameter
fields.notes: Target length of a single side of the world border, in meters.

fields.name: Speed
fields.notes: Number of real-time milli seconds until New Diameter is reached. It appears that vanilla server does not sync world border speed to game ticks, so it gets out of sync with server lag. If the world border is not moving, this is set to 0.

fields.name: Diameter
fields.notes: Length of a single side of the world border, in meters.

fields.name: Warning Time
fields.notes: In seconds as set by /worldborder warning time .

fields.name: Warning Blocks
fields.notes: In meters.

clientbound.name: Set Camera
clientbound.notes:
Sets the entity that the player renders from. This is normally used when the player left-clicks an entity while in spectator mode.

The player's camera will move with the entity and look where it is looking. The entity is often another player, but can be any type of entity. The player is unable to move this entity (move packets will act as if they are coming from the other entity).

If the given entity is not loaded by the player, this packet is ignored. To return control to the player, send this packet with their entity ID.

The vanilla server resets this (sends it back to the default entity) whenever the spectated entity is killed or the player sneaks, but only if they were spectating an entity. It also sends this packet whenever the player switches out of spectator mode (even if they weren't spectating an entity).

The vanilla client also loads certain shaders for given entities:

fields.name: Camera ID
fields.notes: ID of the entity to set the client's camera to.

clientbound.name: Set Center Chunk
clientbound.notes:
Sets the center position of the client's chunk loading area. The area is square-shaped, spanning 2 × server view distance + 7 chunks on both axes (width, not radius!). Since the area's width is always an odd number, there is no ambiguity as to which chunk is the center.

The vanilla client never renders or simulates chunks located outside the loading area, but keeps them in memory (unless explicitly unloaded by the server while still in range), and only automatically unloads a chunk when another chunk is loaded at coordinates congruent to the old chunk's coordinates modulo (2 × server view distance + 7). This means that a chunk may reappear after leaving and later re-entering the loading area through successive uses of this packet, unless it is replaced in the meantime by a different chunk in the same "slot".

The vanilla client ignores attempts to load or unload chunks located outside the loading area. This applies even to unloads targeting chunks that are still loaded, but currently located outside the loading area (per the previous paragraph).

The vanilla server does not rely on any specific behavior for chunks leaving the loading area, and custom clients need not replicate the above exactly. A client may instead choose to immediately unload any chunks outside the loading area, to use a different modulus, or to ignore the loading area completely and keep chunks loaded regardless of their location until the server requests to unload them. Servers aiming for maximal interoperability should always explicitly unload any loaded chunks before they go outside the loading area.

The center chunk is normally the chunk the player is in, but apart from the implications on chunk loading, the (vanilla) client takes no issue with this not being the case. Indeed, as long as chunks are sent only within the default loading area centered on the world origin, it is not necessary to send this packet at all. This may be useful for servers with small bounded worlds, such as minigames, since it ensures chunks never need to be resent after the client has joined, saving on bandwidth.

The vanilla server sends this packet whenever the player moves across a chunk border horizontally, and also (according to testing) for any integer change in the vertical axis, even if it doesn't go across a chunk section border.

fields.name: Chunk X
fields.notes: Chunk X coordinate of the loading area center.

fields.name: Chunk Z
fields.notes: Chunk Z coordinate of the loading area center.

clientbound.name: Set Render Distance
clientbound.notes: Sent by the integrated singleplayer server when changing render distance. This packet is sent by the server when the client reappears in the overworld after leaving the end.

fields.name: View Distance
fields.notes: Render distance (2-32).

clientbound.name: Set Cursor Item
clientbound.notes: Replaces or sets the inventory item that's being dragged with the mouse.

clientbound.name: Set Default Spawn Position
clientbound.notes:
Sent by the server after login to specify the coordinates of the spawn point (the point at which players spawn at, and which the compass points to). It can be sent at any time to update the point compasses point at.

Before receiving this packet, the client uses the default position 8, 64, 8, and angle 0.0.

fields.name: Dimension Name
fields.notes: Name of spawn dimension.

fields.name: Location
fields.notes: Spawn location.

fields.name: Yaw
fields.notes: Yaw after respawning.

fields.name: Pitch
fields.notes: Pitch after respawning.

clientbound.name: Display Objective
clientbound.notes: This is sent to the client when it should display a scoreboard.

fields.name: Position
fields.notes: The position of the scoreboard. 0: list, 1: sidebar, 2: below name, 3 - 18: team-specific sidebar, indexed as 3 + team color.

fields.name: Score Name
fields.notes: The unique name for the scoreboard to be displayed.

clientbound.name: Set Entity Metadata
clientbound.notes: Updates one or more metadata properties for an existing entity. Any properties not included in the Metadata field are left unchanged.

clientbound.name: Link Entities
clientbound.notes: This packet is sent when an entity has been leashed to another entity.

fields.name: Attached Entity ID
fields.notes: Attached entity's EID.

fields.name: Holding Entity ID
fields.notes: ID of the entity holding the lead. Set to -1 to detach.

clientbound.name: Set Equipment
clientbound.notes: Equipment slot can be one of the following:

fields.name: Entity ID
fields.notes: Entity's ID.

clientbound.name: Set Experience
clientbound.notes: Sent by the server when the client should change experience levels.

fields.name: Experience bar
fields.notes: Between 0 and 1.

fields.name: Total Experience
fields.notes: See Experience#Leveling up on the Minecraft Wiki for Total Experience to Level conversion.

clientbound.name: Set Health
clientbound.notes:
Sent by the server to set the health of the player it is sent to.

Food saturation acts as a food “overcharge”. Food values will not decrease while the saturation is over zero. New players logging in or respawning automatically get a saturation of 5.0. Eating food increases the saturation as well as the food bar.

fields.name: Health
fields.notes: 0 or less = dead, 20 = full HP.

fields.name: Food Saturation
fields.notes: Seems to vary from 0.0 to 5.0 in integer increments.

clientbound.name: Set Held Item (clientbound)
clientbound.notes: Sent to change the player's slot selection.

fields.name: Slot
fields.notes: The slot which the player has selected (0–8).

clientbound.name: Update Objectives
clientbound.notes: This is sent to the client when it should create a new scoreboard objective or remove one.

fields.name: Objective Name
fields.notes: A unique name for the objective.

fields.name: Mode
fields.notes: 0 to create the scoreboard. 1 to remove the scoreboard. 2 to update the display text.

fields.name: Objective Value
fields.notes: Only if mode is 0 or 2.The text to be displayed for the score.

fields.name: Type
fields.notes: Only if mode is 0 or 2. 0 = "integer", 1 = "hearts".

fields.name: Has Number Format
fields.notes: Only if mode is 0 or 2. Whether this objective has a set number format for the scores.

fields.name: Number Format
fields.notes: Only if mode is 0 or 2 and the previous boolean is true. Determines how the score number should be formatted.

fields.name: 0: blank
fields.notes: Show nothing.

fields.name: Entity ID
fields.notes: Vehicle's EID.

fields.name: Passengers
fields.notes: EIDs of entity's passengers.

clientbound.name: Update Teams
clientbound.notes:
Creates and updates teams.

Team Color: The color of a team defines how the names of the team members are visualized; any formatting code can be used. The following table lists all the possible values.

fields.name: Team Name
fields.notes: A unique name for the team. (Shared with scoreboard).

fields.name: Method
fields.notes: Determines the layout of the remaining packet.

fields.name: Friendly Flags
fields.notes: Bit mask. 0x01: Allow friendly fire, 0x02: can see invisible players on the same team.

fields.name: Name Tag Visibility
fields.notes: 0 = ALWAYS, 1 = NEVER, 2 = HIDE_FOR_OTHER_TEAMS, 3 = HIDE_FOR_OWN_TEAMS

fields.name: Collision Rule
fields.notes: 0 = ALWAYS, 1 = NEVER, 2 = PUSH_OTHER_TEAMS, 3 = PUSH_OWN_TEAM

fields.name: Team Color
fields.notes: Used to color the names of players on the team; see below.

fields.name: Team Prefix
fields.notes: Displayed before the names of players that are part of this team.

fields.name: Team Suffix
fields.notes: Displayed after the names of players that are part of this team.

fields.name: Entities
fields.notes: Identifiers for the entities in this team. For players, this is their username; for other entities, it is their UUID.

fields.name: Friendly Flags
fields.notes: Bit mask. 0x01: Allow friendly fire, 0x02: can see invisible entities on the same team.

fields.name: Name Tag Visibility
fields.notes: 0 = ALWAYS, 1 = NEVER, 2 = HIDE_FOR_OTHER_TEAMS, 3 = HIDE_FOR_OWN_TEAMS

fields.name: Collision Rule
fields.notes: 0 = ALWAYS, 1 = NEVER, 2 = PUSH_OTHER_TEAMS, 3 = PUSH_OWN_TEAM

fields.name: Team Color
fields.notes: Used to color the names of players on the team; see below.

fields.name: Team Prefix
fields.notes: Displayed before the names of players that are part of this team.

fields.name: Team Suffix
fields.notes: Displayed after the names of players that are part of this team.

clientbound.name: Update Score
clientbound.notes: This is sent to the client when it should update a scoreboard item.

fields.name: Entity Name
fields.notes: The entity whose score this is. For players, this is their username; for other entities, it is their UUID.

fields.name: Objective Name
fields.notes: The name of the objective the score belongs to.

fields.name: Value
fields.notes: The score to be displayed next to the entry.

fields.name: Display Name
fields.notes: The custom display name.

fields.name: Number Format
fields.notes: Determines how the score number should be formatted.

fields.name: 0: blank
fields.notes: Show nothing.

fields.name: Simulation Distance
fields.notes: The distance that the client will process specific things, such as entities.

clientbound.name: Update Time
clientbound.notes:
Time is based on ticks, where 20 ticks happen every second. There are 24000 ticks in a day, making Minecraft days exactly 20 minutes long.

The time of day is based on the timestamp modulo 24000. 0 is sunrise, 6000 is noon, 12000 is sunset, and 18000 is midnight.

The default SMP server increments the time by 20 every second.

fields.name: World Age
fields.notes: In ticks; not changed by server commands.

fields.name: Time of day
fields.notes: The world (or region) time, in ticks.

fields.name: Time of day increasing
fields.notes: If true, the client should automatically advance the time of day according to its ticking rate.

fields.name: Fade In
fields.notes: Ticks to spend fading in.

fields.name: Stay
fields.notes: Ticks to keep the title displayed.

fields.name: Fade Out
fields.notes: Ticks to spend fading out, not when to start fading out.

clientbound.name: Entity Sound Effect
clientbound.notes: Plays a sound effect from an entity, either by hardcoded ID or Identifier. Sound IDs and names can be found here .

fields.name: Sound Event
fields.notes: ID in the minecraft:sound_event registry, or an inline definition.

fields.name: Sound Category
fields.notes: The category that this sound will be played from ( current categories ).

fields.name: Volume
fields.notes: 1.0 is 100%, capped between 0.0 and 1.0 by vanilla clients.

fields.name: Pitch
fields.notes: Float between 0.5 and 2.0 by vanilla clients.

fields.name: Seed
fields.notes: Seed used to pick sound variant.

clientbound.name: Sound Effect
clientbound.notes: Plays a sound effect at the given location, either by hardcoded ID or Identifier. Sound IDs and names can be found here .

fields.name: Sound Event
fields.notes: ID in the minecraft:sound_event registry, or an inline definition.

fields.name: Sound Category
fields.notes: The category that this sound will be played from ( current categories ).

fields.name: Effect Position X
fields.notes: Effect X multiplied by 8 ( fixed-point number with only 3 bits dedicated to the fractional part).

fields.name: Effect Position Y
fields.notes: Effect Y multiplied by 8 ( fixed-point number with only 3 bits dedicated to the fractional part).

fields.name: Effect Position Z
fields.notes: Effect Z multiplied by 8 ( fixed-point number with only 3 bits dedicated to the fractional part).

fields.name: Volume
fields.notes: 1.0 is 100%, capped between 0.0 and 1.0 by vanilla clients.

fields.name: Pitch
fields.notes: Float between 0.5 and 2.0 by vanilla clients.

fields.name: Seed
fields.notes: Seed used to pick sound variant.

clientbound.name: Start Configuration
clientbound.notes:
Sent during gameplay in order to redo the configuration process. The client must respond with Acknowledge Configuration for the process to start.

This packet switches the connection state to configuration .

clientbound.name: Stop Sound
clientbound.notes: Categories:

fields.name: Flags
fields.notes: Controls which fields are present.

fields.name: Source
fields.notes: Only if flags is 3 or 1 (bit mask 0x1). See below. If not present, then sounds from all sources are cleared.

fields.name: Sound
fields.notes: Only if flags is 2 or 3 (bit mask 0x2). A sound effect name, see Custom Sound Effect . If not present, then all sounds are cleared.

clientbound.name: Store Cookie (play)
clientbound.notes: Stores some arbitrary data on the client, which persists between server transfers. The vanilla client only accepts cookies of up to 5 kiB in size.

fields.name: Key
fields.notes: The identifier of the cookie.

fields.name: Payload
fields.notes: The data of the cookie.

clientbound.name: System Chat Message
clientbound.notes: Sends the client a raw system message.

fields.name: Content
fields.notes: Limited to 262144 bytes.

fields.name: Overlay
fields.notes: Whether the message is an actionbar or chat message. See also #Set Action Bar Text .

clientbound.name: Set Tab List Header And Footer
clientbound.notes: This packet may be used by custom servers to display additional information above/below the tab list. It is never sent by the vanilla server.

fields.name: Header
fields.notes: To remove the header, send an empty text component: {"text":""} .

fields.name: Footer
