fields.notes: To remove the footer, send an empty text component: {"text":""} .

clientbound.name: Tag Query Response
clientbound.notes: Sent in response to Query Block Entity Tag or Query Entity Tag .

fields.name: Transaction ID
fields.notes: Can be compared to the one sent in the original query packet.

fields.name: NBT
fields.notes: The NBT of the block or entity. May be a TAG_END (0), in which case no NBT is present.

clientbound.name: Pickup Item
clientbound.notes: Sent by the server when someone picks up an item lying on the ground — its sole purpose appears to be the animation of the item flying towards you. It doesn't destroy the entity in the client memory, and it doesn't add it to your inventory. The server only checks for items to be picked up after each Set Player Position (and Set Player Position And Rotation ) packet sent by the client. The collector entity can be any entity; it does not have to be a player. The collected entity can also be any entity, but the vanilla server only uses this for items, experience orbs, and the different varieties of arrows.

fields.name: Pickup Item Count
fields.notes: Seems to be 1 for XP orbs, otherwise the number of items in the stack.

clientbound.name: Synchronize Vehicle Position
clientbound.notes: Teleports the entity on the client without changing the reference point of movement deltas in future Update Entity Position packets. Seems to be used to make relative adjustments to vehicle positions; more information needed.

fields.name: Yaw
fields.notes: Rotation on the Y axis, in degrees.

fields.name: Pitch
fields.notes: Rotation on the Y axis, in degrees.

clientbound.name: Test Instance Block Status
clientbound.notes: Updates the status of the currently open Test Instance Block screen, if any.

fields.name: Size X
fields.notes: Only present if Has Size is true.

fields.name: Size Y
fields.notes: Only present if Has Size is true.

fields.name: Size Z
fields.notes: Only present if Has Size is true.

clientbound.name: Set Ticking State
clientbound.notes: Used to adjust the ticking rate of the client, and whether it's frozen.

clientbound.name: Step Tick
clientbound.notes: Advances the client processing by the specified number of ticks. Has no effect unless client ticking is frozen.

clientbound.name: Transfer (play)
clientbound.notes: Notifies the client that it should transfer to the given server. Cookies previously stored are preserved between server transfers.

fields.name: Host
fields.notes: The hostname or IP of the server.

fields.name: Port
fields.notes: The port of the server.

clientbound.name: Update Advancements
clientbound.notes: Advancement structure:

fields.name: Reset/Clear
fields.notes: Whether to reset/clear the current advancements.

fields.name: Value
fields.notes: See below

fields.name: Identifiers
fields.notes: The identifiers of the advancements that should be removed.

fields.name: Value
fields.notes: See below.

clientbound.name: Update Attributes
clientbound.notes:
Sets attributes on the given entity.

Modifier Data structure:

fields.name: Value
fields.notes: See below.

fields.name: Modifiers
fields.notes: See Attribute#Modifiers . Modifier Data defined below.

fields.name: Effect ID
fields.notes: See this table .

fields.name: Amplifier
fields.notes: Vanilla client displays effect level as Amplifier + 1.

fields.name: Duration
fields.notes: Duration in ticks. (-1 for infinite)

fields.name: Flags
fields.notes: Bit field, see below.

fields.name: Property Sets
fields.notes: Prefixed Array

clientbound.name: Update Tags (play)
clientbound.notes: A tag looks like this:

fields.name: Registry to tags map
fields.type: ns.PrefixedArray[struct { Registry ns.Identifier; Tags ns.PrefixedTagArray // FIXME: See below }]
fields.notes: Prefixed Array

clientbound.name: Custom Report Details
clientbound.notes: Contains a list of key-value text entries that are included in any crash or disconnection report generated during connection to the server.

fields.name: Details
fields.notes: Prefixed Array (32)

clientbound.name: Server Links
clientbound.notes: This packet contains a list of links that the vanilla client will display in the menu available from the pause menu. Link labels can be built-in or custom (i.e., any text).

fields.name: Links
fields.type: ns.PrefixedArray[struct { IsBuilt-in ns.Boolean; Label ns.VarIntTextComponent; Url ns.String }]
fields.notes: Prefixed Array

clientbound.name: Waypoint
clientbound.notes: Adds, removes, or updates an entry that will be tracked on the player locator bar.

fields.name: Operation
fields.notes: 0: track, 1: untrack, 2: update.

fields.name: Identifier
fields.notes: Something that uniquely identifies this specific waypoint.

fields.name: Icon style
fields.notes: Path to the waypoint style JSON: assets/<namespace>/waypoint_style/<value>.json.

fields.name: Waypoint type
fields.notes: Defines how the following field is read.

clientbound.name: Clear Dialog (play)
clientbound.notes: If we're currently in a dialog screen, then this removes the current screen and switches back to the previous one.

clientbound.name: Show Dialog (play)
clientbound.notes: Show a custom dialog screen to the client.

fields.name: Dialog
fields.notes: ID in the minecraft:dialog registry, or an inline definition as described at Java Edition protocol/Registry data#Dialog .

serverbound.name: Confirm Teleportation
serverbound.notes: Sent by client as confirmation of Synchronize Player Position .

fields.name: Teleport ID
fields.notes: The ID given by the Synchronize Player Position packet.

serverbound.name: Query Block Entity Tag
serverbound.notes: Used when F3 + I is pressed while looking at a block.

fields.name: Transaction ID
fields.notes: An incremental ID so that the client can verify that the response matches.

fields.name: Location
fields.notes: The location of the block to check.

serverbound.name: Change Difficulty
serverbound.notes: Must have at least op level 2 to use. Appears to only be used on singleplayer; the difficulty buttons are still disabled in multiplayer.

fields.name: New difficulty
fields.notes: 0: peaceful, 1: easy, 2: normal, 3: hard.

serverbound.name: Change Game Mode
serverbound.notes: Requests for the server to update our game mode. Has no effect on vanilla servers if the client doesn't have the required permissions.

fields.name: Game mode
fields.notes: 0: survival, 1: creative, 2: adventure, 3: spectator.

fields.name: Command
fields.notes: The command typed by the client excluding the / .

fields.name: Command
fields.notes: The command typed by the client excluding the / .

fields.name: Timestamp
fields.notes: The timestamp that the command was executed.

fields.name: Salt
fields.notes: The salt for the following argument signatures.

fields.name: Signature
fields.notes: The signature that verifies the argument. Always 256 bytes and is not length-prefixed.

serverbound.name: Chat Message
serverbound.notes:
Used to send a chat message to the server. The message may not be longer than 256 characters or else the server will kick the client.

The server will broadcast a Player Chat Message packet with Chat Type minecraft:chat to all players that haven't disabled chat (including the player that sent the message). See Java Edition protocol/Chat#Processing chat for more information.

fields.name: Message
fields.notes: Content of the message

fields.name: Timestamp
fields.notes: Number of milliseconds since the epoch (1 Jan 1970, midnight, UTC)

fields.name: Salt
fields.notes: The salt used to verify the signature hash. Randomly generated by the client

fields.name: Signature
fields.notes: The signature used to verify the chat message's authentication. When present, always 256 bytes and not length-prefixed. This is a SHA256 with RSA digital signature computed over the following: The number 1 as a 4-byte int. Always 00 00 00 01. The player's 16-byte UUID. The chat session (a 16-byte UUID randomly generated by the client). The index of the message within this chat session as a 4-byte int. First message is 0, next message is 1, etc. Incremented each time the client sends a chat message. The salt (from above) as an 8-byte long. The timestamp (from above) converted from milliseconds to seconds, so divide by 1000, as an 8-byte long. The length of the message in bytes (from above) as a 4-byte int. The message bytes. The number of messages in the last seen set, as a 4-byte int. Always in the range [0,20]. For each message in the last seen set, from oldest to newest, the 256-byte signature of that message. The client's chat private key is used for the message signature.

fields.name: Message Count
fields.notes: Number of signed clientbound chat messages the client has seen from the server since the last serverbound chat message from this client. The server will use this to update its last seen list for the client.

fields.name: Acknowledged
fields.notes: Bitmask of which message signatures from the last seen set were used to sign this message. The most recent is the highest bit. If there are fewer than 20 messages in the last seen set, the lower bits will be zeros.

fields.name: Checksum
fields.notes: Checksum is computed over all the message signature checksums in the last seen set, from oldest to newest. Both the packet checksum and signature checksums use the same logic as Java's Arrays.hashCode(byte[]) implementation. The packet checksum additionally casts the resulting int to a byte, and if that byte is 0 returns 1, otherwise returns said byte

fields.name: Public Key
fields.notes: A byte array of an X.509-encoded public key.

fields.name: Key Signature
fields.notes: The signature consists of the player UUID, the key expiration timestamp, and the public key data. These values are hashed using SHA-1 and signed using Mojang's private RSA key.

serverbound.name: Chunk Batch Received
serverbound.notes:
Notifies the server that the chunk batch has been received by the client. The server uses the value sent in this packet to adjust the number of chunks to be sent in a batch.

The vanilla server will stop sending further chunk data until the client acknowledges the sent chunk batch. After the first acknowledgement, the server adjusts this number to allow up to 10 unacknowledged batches.

fields.name: Chunks per tick
fields.notes: Desired chunks per tick.

serverbound.name: Client Status
serverbound.notes: Action ID values:

fields.name: Action ID
fields.notes: See below

serverbound.name: Client Information (play)
serverbound.notes:
Sent when the player connects, or when settings are changed.

Displayed Skin Parts flags:

fields.name: Locale
fields.notes: e.g. en_GB .

fields.name: View Distance
fields.notes: Client-side render distance, in chunks.

fields.name: Chat Mode
fields.notes: 0: enabled, 1: commands only, 2: hidden. See Java Edition protocol/Chat#Client chat mode for more information.

fields.name: Chat Colors
fields.notes: “Colors” multiplayer setting. The vanilla server stores this value but does nothing with it (see MC-64867 ). Some third-party servers disable all coloring in chat and system messages when it is false.

fields.name: Displayed Skin Parts
fields.notes: Bit mask, see below.

fields.name: Main Hand
fields.notes: 0: Left, 1: Right.

fields.name: Enable text filtering
fields.notes: Enables filtering of text on signs and written book titles. The vanilla client sets this according to the profanityFilterPreferences.profanityFilterOn account attribute indicated by the Mojang API endpoint for player attributes . In offline mode, it is always false.

fields.name: Allow server listings
fields.notes: Servers usually list online players; this option should let you not show up in that list.

fields.name: Particle Status
fields.notes: 0: all, 1: decreased, 2: minimal

serverbound.name: Command Suggestions Request
serverbound.notes: Sent when the client needs to tab-complete a minecraft:ask_server suggestion type.

fields.name: Transaction Id
fields.notes: The ID of the transaction that the server will send back to the client in the response of this packet. Client generates this and increments it each time it sends another tab completion that doesn't get a response.

fields.name: Text
fields.notes: All the text behind the cursor including the / (e.g. to the left of the cursor in left-to-right languages like English).

serverbound.name: Acknowledge Configuration
serverbound.notes:
Sent by the client upon receiving a Start Configuration packet from the server.

This packet switches the connection state to configuration .

serverbound.name: Click Container Button
serverbound.notes: Used when clicking on window buttons. Until 1.14, this was only used by enchantment tables.

fields.name: Window ID
fields.notes: The ID of the window sent by Open Screen .

fields.name: Button ID
fields.notes: Meaning depends on window type; see below.

serverbound.name: Click Container
serverbound.notes:
This packet is sent by the client when the player clicks on a slot in a window.

See Java Edition protocol/Inventory for further information about how slots are indexed.

After performing the action, the server compares the results to the slot change information included in the packet, as applied on top of the server's view of the container's state prior to the action. For any slots that do not match, it sends Set Container Slot packets containing the correct results. If State ID does not match the last ID sent by the server, it will instead send a full Set Container Content to resynchronize the client.

When right-clicking on a stack of items, half the stack will be picked up and half left in the slot. If the stack is an odd number, the half left in the slot will be the smaller of the amounts.

The distinct type of click performed by the client is determined by the combination of the Mode and Button fields.

fields.name: Window ID
fields.notes: The ID of the window that was clicked. 0 for player inventory. The server ignores any packets targeting a Window ID other than the current one, including ignoring 0 when any other window is open.

fields.name: State ID
fields.notes: The last received State ID from either a Set Container Slot or a Set Container Content packet.

fields.name: Slot
fields.notes: The clicked slot number, see below.

fields.name: Button
fields.notes: The button used in the click, see below.

fields.name: Mode
fields.notes: Inventory operation mode, see below.

fields.name: Slot data
fields.notes: New data for this slot, in the client's opinion; see below.

fields.name: Carried item
fields.notes: Item carried by the cursor.

serverbound.name: Close Container
serverbound.notes:
This packet is sent by the client when closing a window.

vanilla clients send a Close Window packet with Window ID 0 to close their inventory, even though there is never an Open Screen packet for the inventory.

fields.name: Window ID
fields.notes: This is the ID of the window that was closed. 0 for player inventory.

serverbound.name: Change Container Slot State
serverbound.notes: This packet is sent by the client when toggling the state of a Crafter.

fields.name: Slot ID
fields.notes: This is the ID of the slot that was changed.

fields.name: Window ID
fields.notes: This is the ID of the window that was changed.

fields.name: State
fields.notes: The new state of the slot. True for enabled, false for disabled.

serverbound.name: Cookie Response (play)
serverbound.notes: Response to a Cookie Request (play) from the server. The vanilla server only accepts responses of up to 5 kiB in size.

fields.name: Key
fields.notes: The identifier of the cookie.

fields.name: Payload
fields.notes: The data of the cookie.

serverbound.name: Serverbound Plugin Message (play)
serverbound.notes:
Mods and plugins can use this to send their data. Minecraft itself uses some plugin channels . These internal channels are in the minecraft namespace.

More documentation on this: "Minecraft Plugin Channels + Messaging" on Dinnerbone's former blog, archived from the original .

fields.name: Channel
fields.notes: Name of the plugin channel used to send the data.

fields.name: Data
fields.notes: Any data, depending on the channel. Typically this would be a sequence of fields using standard data types, but some unofficial channels have unusual formats. There is no length prefix that applies to all channel types, but the format specific to the channel may or may not include one or more length prefixes (such as the string length prefix in the standard minecraft:brand channel). The vanilla server enforces a length limit of 32767 bytes on this data, but only if the channel type is unrecognized.

serverbound.name: Debug Subscription Request
serverbound.notes:
Sent by the client whenever debug subscriptions, used by debug graphs and renderers , are activated or deactivated. The list in the packet replaces the previous set of active subscriptions. Subscriptions not in the list are deactivated.

If the client does not have permission to receive the requested debug information, the subscriptions are nonetheless retained by the server, and it is not necessary to send this packet again if the permissions change.

fields.name: Subscriptions
fields.notes: List of active debug subscriptions. IDs in the minecraft:debug_subscription registry.

fields.name: Slot
fields.notes: The hotbar slot where the written book is located

fields.name: Entries
fields.notes: Text from each page. Maximum string length is 1024 chars.

fields.name: Title
fields.notes: Title of book. Present if book is being signed, not present if book is being edited.

serverbound.name: Query Entity Tag
serverbound.notes: Used when F3 + I is pressed while looking at an entity.

fields.name: Transaction ID
fields.notes: An incremental ID so that the client can verify that the response matches.

fields.name: Entity ID
fields.notes: The ID of the entity to query.

serverbound.name: Interact
serverbound.notes:
This packet is sent from the client to the server when the client attacks or right-clicks another entity (a player, minecart, etc).

A vanilla server only accepts this packet if the entity being attacked/used is visible without obstruction and within a 4-unit radius of the player's position.

The target X, Y, and Z fields represent the difference between the vector location of the cursor at the time of the packet and the entity's position.

Note that middle-click in creative mode is interpreted by the client and sent as a Set Creative Mode Slot packet instead.

Interaction with the ender dragon is an odd special case characteristic of release deadline–driven design. 8 consecutive entity IDs following the dragon's ID ( id + 1, id + 2, ..., id + 8) are reserved for the 8 hitboxes that make up the dragon:

fields.name: Entity ID
fields.notes: The ID of the entity to interact. Note the special case described below.

fields.name: Type
fields.notes: 0: interact, 1: attack, 2: interact at.

fields.name: Target X
fields.notes: Only if Type is interact at.

fields.name: Target Y
fields.notes: Only if Type is interact at.

fields.name: Target Z
fields.notes: Only if Type is interact at.

fields.name: Hand
fields.notes: Only if Type is interact or interact at; 0: main hand, 1: off hand.

fields.name: Sneak Key Pressed
fields.notes: If the client is pressing the sneak key. Has the same effect as a Player Command Press/Release sneak key preceding the interaction, and the state is permanently changed.

serverbound.name: Jigsaw Generate
serverbound.notes: Sent when Generate is pressed on the Jigsaw Block interface.

fields.name: Location
fields.notes: Block entity location.

fields.name: Levels
fields.notes: Value of the levels slider/max depth to generate.

serverbound.name: Serverbound Keep Alive (play)
serverbound.notes: The server will frequently send out a keep-alive (see Clientbound Keep Alive ), each containing a random ID. The client must respond with the same packet.

serverbound.name: Lock Difficulty
serverbound.notes: Must have at least op level 2 to use. Appears to only be used on singleplayer; the difficulty buttons are still disabled in multiplayer.

fields.name: X
fields.notes: Absolute position.

fields.name: Feet Y
fields.notes: Absolute feet position, normally Head Y - 1.62.

fields.name: Z
fields.notes: Absolute position.

fields.name: Flags
fields.notes: Bit field: 0x01: on ground, 0x02: pushing against wall.

serverbound.name: Set Player Position and Rotation
serverbound.notes: A combination of Move Player Rotation and Move Player Position .

fields.name: X
fields.notes: Absolute position.

fields.name: Feet Y
fields.notes: Absolute feet position, normally Head Y - 1.62.

fields.name: Z
fields.notes: Absolute position.

fields.name: Yaw
fields.notes: Absolute rotation on the X Axis, in degrees.

fields.name: Pitch
fields.notes: Absolute rotation on the Y Axis, in degrees.

fields.name: Flags
fields.notes: Bit field: 0x01: on ground, 0x02: pushing against wall.

fields.name: Yaw
fields.notes: Absolute rotation on the X Axis, in degrees.

fields.name: Pitch
fields.notes: Absolute rotation on the Y Axis, in degrees.

fields.name: Flags
fields.notes: Bit field: 0x01: on ground, 0x02: pushing against wall.

serverbound.name: Set Player Movement Flags
serverbound.notes:
This packet, as well as Set Player Position , Set Player Rotation , and Set Player Position and Rotation are called the “serverbound movement packets”. Vanilla clients will send Move Player Position once every 20 ticks, even for a stationary player.

This packet is used to indicate whether the player is on ground (walking/swimming) or airborne (jumping/falling).

When dropping from a sufficient height, fall damage is applied when this state goes from false to true. The amount of damage applied is based on the point where it last changed from true to false. Note that there are several movement related packets containing this state.

fields.name: Flags
fields.notes: Bit field: 0x01: on ground, 0x02: pushing against wall.

serverbound.name: Move Vehicle (serverbound)
serverbound.notes: Sent when a player moves in a client-side-controlled vehicle. Fields are the same as in Set Player Position and Rotation . Note that all fields use absolute positioning and do not allow for relative positioning.

fields.name: X
fields.notes: Absolute position (X coordinate).

fields.name: Y
fields.notes: Absolute position (Y coordinate).

fields.name: Z
fields.notes: Absolute position (Z coordinate).

fields.name: Yaw
fields.notes: Absolute rotation on the vertical axis, in degrees.

fields.name: Pitch
fields.notes: Absolute rotation on the horizontal axis, in degrees.

fields.name: On Ground
fields.notes: (This value does not seem to exist)

serverbound.name: Paddle Boat
serverbound.notes:
Used to visually update whether boat paddles are turning. The server will update the Boat entity metadata to match the values here.

Right paddle turning is set to true when the left button or forward button is held, left paddle turning is set to true when the right button or forward button is held.

serverbound.name: Pick Item From Block
serverbound.notes: Used for pick block functionality (middle click) on blocks to retrieve items from the inventory in survival or creative mode or create them in creative mode. See Controls#Pick Block for more information.

fields.name: Location
fields.notes: The location of the block.

fields.name: Include Data
fields.notes: Used to tell the server to include block data in the new stack, works only if in creative mode.

serverbound.name: Pick Item From Entity
serverbound.notes: Used for pick block functionality (middle click) on entities to retrieve items from the inventory in survival or creative mode or create them in creative mode. See Controls#Pick Block for more information.

fields.name: Entity ID
fields.notes: The ID of the entity to pick.

fields.name: Include Data
fields.notes: Unused by the vanilla server.

fields.name: Payload
fields.notes: May be any number. vanilla clients use a system-dependent time value, which is counted in milliseconds.

serverbound.name: Place Recipe
serverbound.notes: This packet is sent when a player clicks a recipe in the crafting book that is craftable (white border).

fields.name: Recipe ID
fields.notes: ID of recipe previously defined in Recipe Book Add .

fields.name: Make all
fields.notes: Affects the amount of items processed; true if shift is down when clicked.

serverbound.name: Player Abilities (serverbound)
serverbound.notes: The vanilla client sends this packet when the player starts/stops flying with the Flags parameter changed accordingly.

fields.name: Flags
fields.notes: Bit mask. 0x02: is flying.

serverbound.name: Player Action
serverbound.notes:
Sent when the player mines a block. A vanilla server only accepts digging packets with coordinates within a 6-unit radius between the center of the block and the player's eyes.

Status can be one of seven values:

fields.name: Status
fields.notes: The action the player is taking against the block (see below).

fields.name: Location
fields.notes: Block position.

fields.name: Face
fields.notes: The face being hit (see below).

fields.name: Sequence
fields.notes: Block change sequence number (see #Acknowledge Block Change ).

serverbound.name: Player Command
serverbound.notes:
Sent by the client to indicate that it has performed certain actions: sprinting, exiting a bed, jumping with a horse, and opening a horse's inventory while riding it.

Action ID can be one of the following values:

fields.name: Entity ID
fields.notes: Player ID (ignored by the vanilla server)

fields.name: Action ID
fields.notes: The ID of the action, see below.

fields.name: Jump Boost
fields.notes: Only used by the “start jump with horse” action, in which case it ranges from 0 to 100. In all other cases it is 0.

serverbound.name: Player Input
serverbound.notes:
Sent whenever the player presses or releases certain keys. The flags correspond directly to the states of their corresponding keys—the Sprint flag does not depend on whether the player is actually able to sprint at the moment, etc.

Used by the vanilla server for minecart controls, player inputs in the entity_properties predicate , and sneaking (sprinting is still controlled by Player Command ).

The flags are as follows:

fields.name: Flags
fields.notes: Bit mask; see below

serverbound.name: Player Loaded
serverbound.notes:
Sent by the client to indicate that it is ready to start simulating the player. The vanilla client sends this when the "Loading terrain..." screen is closed . (But see the caveat below.)

The vanilla client skips ticking the player entity until the tick on which this packet is sent (the first tick will happen between this packet and the next Client Tick End ). Other entities and objects will still be ticked.

Once 60 ticks have elapsed since the last Login or Respawn packet, the vanilla client will start ticking the player and skip sending this packet completely , even after the usual conditions for it have been met. This can happen even before the "Start waiting for level chunks" Game Event is received. The loading screen is not affected in any way by this timer (except indirectly by the player falling into the void after ticking has started). Likewise, the vanilla server will assume that the client has loaded if it takes longer than 60 server ticks to send this packet. A more robust way to detect this condition is to count the number of Client Tick End packets sent by the client. The first player tick will occur after 60 Client Tick End packets have been sent. To determine when this counter should be restarted following a respawn, the Respawn packet can be sent in a bundle together with a Ping packet.

serverbound.name: Pong (play)
serverbound.notes: Response to the clientbound packet ( Ping ) with the same ID.

fields.name: ID
fields.notes: id is the same as the ping packet

serverbound.name: Change Recipe Book Settings
serverbound.notes: Replaces Recipe Book Data, type 1.

fields.name: Book ID
fields.notes: 0: crafting, 1: furnace, 2: blast furnace, 3: smoker.

serverbound.name: Set Seen Recipe
serverbound.notes: Sent when recipe is first seen in recipe book. Replaces Recipe Book Data, type 0.

fields.name: Recipe ID
fields.notes: ID of recipe previously defined in Recipe Book Add.

serverbound.name: Rename Item
serverbound.notes: Sent as a player is renaming an item in an anvil (each keypress in the anvil UI sends a new Rename Item packet). If the new name is empty, then the item loses its custom name (this is different from setting the custom name to the normal name of the item). The item name may be no longer than 50 characters, and if it is longer than that, then the rename is silently ignored.

fields.name: Item name
fields.notes: The new name of the item.

serverbound.name: Resource Pack Response (play)
serverbound.notes: Result can be one of the following values:

fields.name: UUID
fields.notes: The unique identifier of the resource pack received in the Add Resource Pack (play) request.

fields.name: Result
fields.notes: Result ID (see below).

fields.name: Action
fields.notes: 0: Opened tab, 1: Closed screen.

fields.name: Tab ID
fields.notes: Only present if action is Opened tab.

serverbound.name: Select Trade
serverbound.notes: When a player selects a specific trade offered by a villager NPC.

fields.name: Selected slot
fields.notes: The selected slot in the player's current (trading) inventory.

serverbound.name: Set Beacon Effect
serverbound.notes: Changes the effect of the current beacon.

fields.name: Primary Effect
fields.notes: A Potion ID .

fields.name: Secondary Effect
fields.notes: A Potion ID .

serverbound.name: Set Held Item (serverbound)
serverbound.notes: Sent when the player changes the slot selection.

fields.name: Slot
fields.notes: The slot which the player has selected (0–8).

fields.name: Mode
fields.notes: 0: chain, 1: repeating, 2: impulse.

fields.name: Flags
fields.notes: 0x01: Track Output (if false, the output of the previous command will not be stored within the command block); 0x02: Is conditional; 0x04: Automatic.

fields.name: Track Output
fields.notes: If false, the output of the previous command will not be stored within the command block.

serverbound.name: Set Creative Mode Slot
serverbound.notes:
While the user is in the standard inventory (i.e., not a crafting bench) in Creative mode, the player will send this packet.

Clicking in the creative inventory menu is quite different from non-creative inventory management. Picking up an item with the mouse actually deletes the item from the server, and placing an item into a slot or dropping it out of the inventory actually tells the server to create the item from scratch. (This can be verified by clicking an item that you don't mind deleting, then severing the connection to the server; the item will be nowhere to be found when you log back in.) As a result of this implementation strategy, the "Destroy Item" slot is just a client-side implementation detail that means "I don't intend to recreate this item.". Additionally, the long listings of items (by category, etc.) are a client-side interface for choosing which item to create. Picking up an item from such listings sends no packets to the server; only when you put it somewhere does it tell the server to create the item in that location.

This action can be described as "set inventory slot". Picking up an item sets the slot to item ID -1. Placing an item into an inventory slot sets the slot to the specified item. Dropping an item (by clicking outside the window) effectively sets slot -1 to the specified item, which causes the server to spawn the item entity, etc.. All other inventory slots are numbered the same as the non-creative inventory (including slots for the 2x2 crafting menu, even though they aren't visible in the vanilla client).

fields.name: Slot
fields.notes: Inventory slot.

serverbound.name: Program Jigsaw Block
serverbound.notes: Sent when Done is pressed on the Jigsaw Block interface.

fields.name: Location
fields.notes: Block entity location

fields.name: Final state
fields.notes: "Turns into" on the GUI, final_state in NBT.

fields.name: Joint type
fields.notes: rollable if the attached piece can be rotated, else aligned .

serverbound.name: Program Structure Block
serverbound.notes: Possible actions:

fields.name: Location
fields.notes: Block entity location.

fields.name: Action
fields.notes: An additional action to perform beyond simply saving the given data; see below.

fields.name: Mode
fields.notes: One of SAVE (0), LOAD (1), CORNER (2), DATA (3).

fields.name: Offset X
fields.notes: Between -48 and 48.

fields.name: Offset Y
fields.notes: Between -48 and 48.

fields.name: Offset Z
fields.notes: Between -48 and 48.

fields.name: Size X
fields.notes: Between 0 and 48.

fields.name: Size Y
fields.notes: Between 0 and 48.

fields.name: Size Z
fields.notes: Between 0 and 48.

fields.name: Mirror
fields.notes: One of NONE (0), LEFT_RIGHT (1), FRONT_BACK (2).

fields.name: Rotation
fields.notes: One of NONE (0), CLOCKWISE_90 (1), CLOCKWISE_180 (2), COUNTERCLOCKWISE_90 (3).

fields.name: Integrity
fields.notes: Between 0 and 1.

fields.name: Flags
fields.notes: 0x01: Ignore entities; 0x02: Show air; 0x04: Show bounding box; 0x08: Strict placement.

serverbound.name: Set Test Block
serverbound.notes: Updates the value of the Test Block at the given position.

fields.name: Mode
fields.notes: 0: start, 1: log, 2: fail, 3: accept

serverbound.name: Update Sign
serverbound.notes:
This message is sent from the client to the server when the “Done” button is pushed after placing a sign.

The server only accepts this packet after Open Sign Editor , otherwise this packet is silently ignored.

fields.name: Location
fields.notes: Block Coordinates.

fields.name: Is Front Text
fields.notes: Whether the updated text is in front or on the back of the sign

fields.name: Line 1
fields.notes: First line of text in the sign.

fields.name: Line 2
fields.notes: Second line of text in the sign.

fields.name: Line 3
fields.notes: Third line of text in the sign.

fields.name: Line 4
fields.notes: Fourth line of text in the sign.

serverbound.name: Swing Arm
serverbound.notes: Sent when the player's arm swings.

fields.name: Hand
fields.notes: Hand used for the animation. 0: main hand, 1: off hand.

serverbound.name: Teleport To Entity
serverbound.notes:
Teleports the player to the given entity. The player must be in spectator mode.

The vanilla client only uses this to teleport to players, but it appears to accept any type of entity. The entity does not need to be in the same dimension as the player; if necessary, the player will be respawned in the right world. If the given entity cannot be found (or isn't loaded), this packet will be ignored.

fields.name: Target Player
fields.notes: UUID of the player to teleport to (can also be an entity UUID).

serverbound.name: Test Instance Block Action
serverbound.notes: Tries to perform an action the Test Instance Block at the given position.

fields.name: Action
fields.notes: 0: init, 1: query, 2: set, 3: reset, 4: save, 5: export, 6: run.

fields.name: Test
fields.notes: ID in the minecraft:test_instance registry.

fields.name: Rotation
fields.notes: 0: none, 1: clockwise 90°, 2: clockwise 180°, 3: counter-clockwise 90°.

fields.name: Status
fields.notes: 0: cleared, 1: running, 2: finished.

serverbound.name: Use Item On
serverbound.notes:
Upon placing a block, this packet is sent once.

The Cursor Position X/Y/Z fields (also known as in-block coordinates) are calculated using raytracing. The unit corresponds to sixteen pixels in the default resource pack. For example, let's say a slab is being placed against the south face of a full block. The Cursor Position X will be higher if the player was pointing near the right (east) edge of the face, lower if pointing near the left. The Cursor Position Y will be used to determine whether it will appear as a bottom slab (values 0.0–0.5) or as a top slab (values 0.5-1.0). The Cursor Position Z should be 1.0 since the player was looking at the southernmost part of the block.

Inside block is true when a player's head (specifically eyes) are inside of a block's collision. In 1.13 and later versions, collision is rather complicated and individual blocks can have multiple collision boxes. For instance, a ring of vines has a non-colliding hole in the middle. This value is only true when the player is directly in the box. In practice, though, this value is only used by scaffolding to place in front of the player when sneaking inside of it (other blocks will place behind when you intersect with them -- try with glass for instance).

fields.name: Hand
fields.notes: The hand from which the block is placed; 0: main hand, 1: off hand.

fields.name: Location
fields.notes: Block position.

fields.name: Face
fields.notes: The face on which the block is placed (as documented at Player Action ).

fields.name: Cursor Position X
fields.notes: The position of the crosshair on the block, from 0 to 1 increasing from west to east.

fields.name: Cursor Position Y
fields.notes: The position of the crosshair on the block, from 0 to 1 increasing from bottom to top.

fields.name: Cursor Position Z
fields.notes: The position of the crosshair on the block, from 0 to 1 increasing from north to south.

fields.name: Inside block
fields.notes: True when the player's head is inside of a block.

fields.name: World Border Hit
fields.notes: Seems to always be false, even when interacting with blocks around or outside the world border, or while the player is outside the border.

fields.name: Sequence
fields.notes: Block change sequence number (see #Acknowledge Block Change ).

serverbound.name: Use Item
serverbound.notes:
Sent when pressing the Use Item key (default: right click) with an item in hand.

The player's rotation is permanently updated according to the Yaw and Pitch fields before performing the action, unless there is no item in the specified hand.

fields.name: Hand
fields.notes: Hand used for the animation. 0: main hand, 1: off hand.

fields.name: Sequence
fields.notes: Block change sequence number (see #Acknowledge Block Change ).

fields.name: Yaw
fields.notes: Player head rotation around the Y-Axis.

fields.name: Pitch
fields.notes: Player head rotation around the X-Axis.

serverbound.name: Custom Click Action (play)
serverbound.notes: Sent when the client clicks a Text Component with the minecraft:custom click action. This is meant as an alternative to running a command, but will not have any effect on vanilla servers.

fields.name: ID
fields.notes: The identifier for the click action.

fields.name: Payload
fields.notes: The data to send with the click action. May be a TAG_END (0).

fields.name: JSON Response
fields.notes: See Java Edition protocol/Server List Ping#Status Response ; as with all strings, this is prefixed by its length as a VarInt .

fields.name: Timestamp
fields.notes: Should match the one sent by the client.

serverbound.name: Status Request
serverbound.notes: The status can only be requested once, immediately after the handshake, before any ping. The server won't respond otherwise.

fields.name: Timestamp
fields.notes: May be any number, but vanilla clients will always use the timestamp in milliseconds.
